thread.title: ‘Sorry for misunderstanding’: Israeli President defuses Netanyahu’s ‘wall tweet’ row with Mexico
thread.title_full: ‘Sorry for misunderstanding’: Israeli President defuses Netanyahu’s ‘wall tweet’ row with Mexico

author: RT
title: ‘Sorry for misunderstanding’: Israeli President defuses Netanyahu’s ‘wall tweet’ row with Mexico
text:
‘Sorry for misunderstanding’: Israeli President defuses Netanyahu’s ‘wall tweet’ row with Mexico Published time: 1 Feb, 2017 00:06 Get short URL FILE PHOTO Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu (C) walks next to the border fence during a visit in southern Israel near Eilat. © Marc Israel Sellem / Reuters The Mexican leader has accepted an apology offered by the Israeli President who made amends following Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s ‘wall’s a great idea’ tweet that caused a misunderstanding and a diplomatic spat between the two nations. 
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu tweeted on Saturday that it was a “great idea” to erect a wall between Israel and Egypt to curb the influx of illegal migrants from African countries. President Trump is right. I built a wall along Israel's southern border. It stopped all illegal immigration. Great success. Great idea 🇮🇱🇺🇸 — Benjamin Netanyahu (@netanyahu) January 28, 2017 
The message was posted on the social media platform just two days after newly elected US President Donald Trump praised the Sinai barrier as an effective way to battle illegal immigration. 
While Netanyahu never directly mentioned support for the planned US-Mexican wall, within the context of Trump’s remarks to Fox news on Thursday, Netanyahu’s tweet was quickly misconstrued as Israeli endorsement for new US administration’s endeavor. — RT (@RT_com) January 31, 2017 
The tweet inadvertently misinterpreted by Mexico caused a diplomatic row. As the Mexican foreign ministry voiced concern and summoned the Israeli ambassador over the tweet, the country’s Foreign Minister Luis Videgaray, on Monday, called on the Israeli government to clarify and “correct” its position. 
On Monday, Netanyahu clarified that his tweet was written in response to Trump’s praise of Israel’s border with Egypt, blaming the media for reporting “fake news” and unleashing a “Bolshevik hunt” against him at a time when Israeli prosecutors are conducting two criminal probes into his possible abuse of office. 
Reluctant to accept Netanyahu’s explanation, on Tuesday, Mexican president Enrique Pena Nieto spoke by phone with his Israeli counterpart, Reuven Rivlin, who offered an apology on Tel Aviv’s behalf over Netanyahu’s ‘wall’ tweet. 
“The security situation in Israel, and the entire Middle East brought us to the important decision to build a fence on our [southern] border. We have no intention of comparing the security situation in the State of Israel, and the steps forced upon us, to the situation of any of our friends around the world,” Rivlin told Nieto, calling the entire diplomatic fiasco a “misunderstanding.” It was a pleasure to talk to my friend Pres @EPN of Mexico. Our 2 states have many common interests. Hope to see him soon in Jerusalem 🇮🇱🇲🇽 — Reuven Rivlin (@PresidentRuvi) January 31, 2017 
“I am sorry for any hurt caused as a result of this misunderstanding, but we must remember that we are talking about a misunderstanding, and I am sure that we can put the issue behind us,” Rivlin added . 
Nieto for his part welcomed Rivlin’s willingness to find a solution to the diplomatic row, the Jewish Telegraphic Agency (JTA) reported. The Mexican leader acknowledged that Mexico has always been willing to have a “very close relationship” with Israel and to “maintain” mutual cooperation, but “unfortunately this cooperation has been hurt because of this tweet.” Read more ‘Great idea’: Netanyahu tweets support for Trump’s Mexico border wall 
“President Peña Nieto said that the tweet disconcerted Mexico and the Mexican Jewish community and hurt the relationship between both countries. President Rivlin offered an apology for hurting Mexico and hoped that the relationship would resume its channel of cooperation and friendship,” the Mexican Foreign Ministry added after the phone conversation. 
Netanyahu on Tuesday also stressed that Israel and Mexico “will continue to have good relations” as he once again explained the intention of his Saturday’s tweet. 
“I did point out the remarkable success of Israel’s security fence. But I did not comment about the US - Mexico relations,” Netanyahu told the audience at CyberTech conference in Tel Aviv, JTA reports . “We’ve had, and will continue to have, good relations with Mexico. And I believe our ties are much stronger than any passing disagreement or misunderstanding.” 
After three years of construction, Israel in 2013 completed a 152 mile (245 km) long wall from Rafah to Eilat along its border with Egypt. As a result, Netanyahu’s $450 million project managed to halt illegal migration into the Jewish state. 
While 9,570 citizens from African countries entered Israel illegally in the first half of 2012, only 34 managed to sneak into Israel in first six months of 2013 after the completion of the barrier. That is a decrease of over 99 percent , which Trump referred to during his interview with Fox News on Thursday. 
“People want protection and a wall protects,” Trump said during the interview last week. “All you’ve got to do is ask Israel. They were having a total disaster coming across and they had a wall. It’s 99.9 percent stoppage.” 'People want protection and a wall protects. All you have to do is ask Israel...' @realDonaldTrump pic.twitter.com/QeTbiJpaDY
